Congratulations to Samantha Mauch! Samantha is the August Certified Employee of the Month! Samantha is a Math Teacher at O'Leary Middle School.

When asked why she chooses this career she said, "I didn't choose teaching, it chose me. I was going to be an engineer that worked in poor countries all over the world building dams/highways and yet here I am, a teacher. I have learned more about being a good human from the students in my classroom than I would have in any other profession."

O'Leary Middle School Principal Ace Marcellus said, "Dedicated. That one word best describes Sam Mauch. She is dedicated to making sure that our students are taken care of, and know that they are loved. She is dedicated to making sure that we are offering the best math curriculum to our students (for the entire district). She is dedicated to helping out our staff with anything that they need. She is dedicated to improving herself and she works hard to do so every day. Sam is such an asset to have on staff, our students and staff are lucky to have her, and we all know it!"

Here in the TFSD we have an employee who works with families experiencing homelessness to help support their children. She shared this story: Yesterday I went to Fred Meyer to fill a purchase order for school supplies for our homeless students and other students whose families may be struggling at this time. The employees were so kind and helpful. They made sure I had all the discounts available. I was able to get $98.00 more in school supplies. A gentleman shopping in the store heard what I was doing and gave me money to help out even more.

Thanks so much to the community members, business, and service organizations who have donated to our Angel Fund. We are getting needed school supplies and are starting to stock the school food banks. Many families will be helped thanks to your generosity.

If you are struggling to provide school supplies for your children or if you want to help support the children in our community, contact Becky Jaynes at 208-732-7507.

Again, we are so proud of the numerous students who have overcome challenges to keep learning this school year!

Being away from students can be hard on teachers too! On this #MissYouMonday we want to share a post from a couple of weeks ago when the decision was made to close schools. The teacher said:

"Today was rough. I think calling school for the year was the right thing...but I‚Äôm so sad about it. 4th quarter is my FAVORITE. It is so fun. It is the payoff for all your hard work...both for teachers and students. I have certain books I read them and traditions and activities we do. I cement my relationship and lifelong love for them. We bond. We had a whole quarter stolen from us. It‚Äôs not fair. "

We all feel like we are missing out on something during this time and it is important to be understanding as everyone is coping with these emotions. Even though she was struggling, this teacher decided to jump in and support her students in different ways. She made this video of one of the books that made her feel better and is continuing to read books, chapter by chapter, through videos.

post_text: During these uncertain times, many parents struggle to provide for their families. In the Twin Falls School District, we know that healthy children who have their basic needs met are more able to learn. Through partnerships with local leaders, like Glanbia, Clif Bar, Chobani, the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints, and so many others, we are able to provide families with food boxes so that they can focus on staying safe and healthy. Usually, our district has roughly 64% of our students who qualify for free and reduced meal service. We can guess that in times like these, an increasing number of families are falling below the poverty line. The picture shows families lined up at one of our schools to pick up boxes. If you want to help provide for these families contact Becky Jaynes at jaynesbe@tfsd.org and she can help coordinate your donation. Thank you to these incredible community partners and to the TFSD staff members who have been making sure this program continues to support the community.

They researched a dinosaur of their choice using informational text books, online sources and documentaries. Students then completed a graphic organizer that answered the topic, ‚Äúwhy I should have a pet dinosaur.‚Äù In it, they had to include both facts about their dinosaur and opinion pieces to sell their argument (they could mow the yard for us because they are herbivores). They then had to write a rough draft that added an introduction and a conclusion along with
adapting their graphic organizer notes into complete sentences. After an edit, students had to type their final, add an appropriate picture, and email it to their teacher. Once this was completed, students got to papier-m√¢ch√© their dinosaur to display in the library the week of conferences. This project hit several ELA standards including researching, writing and opinion piece, working cooperatively in a group, and presenting.
